Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: 3-Iminophosphine Palladium Catalysts for Atom-Efficient Syntheses
Award.AbstractNarration: The Inorganic, Bioinorganic, and Organometallic Chemistry Program supports the work of Professor Joseph A. Schmidt of the University of Toledo to examine recently discovered palladium 3-iminophosphine (3IP) catalysts for the synthesis of biologically-important molecules such as indoles, epithilone analogues, and glycosyl ureas via more efficient pathways. These targets have particular relevance for diabetes and cancer treatments. Catalytic coupling reactions will be screened and optimized to determine the breadth of the reactions amenable to catalysis and the hydroamination of phenylacetylene and isoprene have been chosen as model reactions to identify the unique, selective, and highly reactive catalytic mechanism. High school students participating in the American Chemical Society's Project SEED conduct research in Professor Schmidt's laboratory. These and other students are recruited from the Latino Youth Summit (for grades 6-12). Professor Schmidt has also introduced a hands-on laboratory component to the highly successful Saturday Morning Science Program at the University of Toledo. This program invites teachers, parents and students of all ages and backgrounds to participate in chemistry experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project, funded through the NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program, involved both teaching objectives and scholarship (research) objectives. Such awards are provided to support faculty members early in their careers in the establishment of their research programs and to expand upon their fledgling teaching and outreach efforts. Throughout the course of this project, many research, educational, and outreach objectives have been achieved, as detailed below.

 

Research Outcomes

 

The overall goal of this research program was to develop new tools to enable more efficient and environmentally friendly synthesis of medicinally-relevant organic molecules. Aspects of green chemistry particularly relevant to pharmaceutical production that were addressed included: the ability to synthesize target molecules at ambient temperature, the efficient utilization of starting reagents to minimize waste and byproducts, and the discovery of novel reactivity pathways to make challenging molecules. Although carrying out these reactions at room temperature (25 oC) may seem normal to the layperson, it should be noted that many industrial syntheses require cooling (to 0 oC or lower) or heating (to 60 oC or higher), which contributes significant financial and environmental costs because of the energy needed to power these temperature changes. Thus, chemistry that functions well at room temperature is a significant development. The second goal involves optimizing atom efficiency, meaning that the maximum number of atoms of the starting materials are incorporated into the desired products. If the goal is to make a product C, most reactions will have the form A + B -> C + D, whereas almost all of the research funded by this grant functions instead as A + B -> C only. Thus, when C is the desired chemical product, there is no byproduct to dispose of or repurpose, making this a 100% atom efficient reaction. Lastly, with the two previous green chemical principles in hand, this research further focused on utilizing synthetic pathways that were previously unknown or had been difficult to accomplish using existing catalysts.

 

During the course of this grant funding, a new class of palladium catalysts was explored and developed. Palladium is a precious metal commonly used in pharmaceutical syntheses and was the subject of the Nobel prize in 2010. Although palladium is an expensive precious metal, the chemistry under investigation throughout this research grant normally uses catalysts containing rhodium, iridium, or gold, all of which are even more expensive than palladium. The new palladium catalysts developed during the course of this research grant achieved the green chemistry goals described above and enabled the formation of new chemical bonds between carbon and nitrogen, carbon and silicon, or carbon and carbon, all important in the synthesis of a variety of important target molecules.

 

In addition to the production of these new palladium catalysts and the related compounds necessary to understand and characterize their reactivity, many new pharmaceutically relevant molecules were produced, including 92 that had never been described in the open literature. Furthermore, a new method of synthesizing cinnarizine (a drug prescribed for the treatment of vertigo and nausea associated with motion sickness) was developed. Additional derivatives of this drug were also produced, and the biological activity of these species is currently being investigated.

 

Teaching/Outreach Outcomes

 

This grant also targeted the development and expansion of teaching and outreach activities at The University of Toledo in concert with the research described above. Highlights of the outcomes fro...

Teaching/Outreach Outcomes This grant also targeted the development and expansion of teaching and outreach activities at The University of Toledo in concert with the research described above. Highlights of the outcomes from these activities included recruiting a total of eleven undergraduate students into the lab to perform experiments contributing to the research projects described above.
